Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research MINERVA: A dedicated, global, precision radial velocity machine for TESS
Award.AbstractNarration:
A research collaboration between Harvard University, George Mason University, the University of California-Riverside, and the University of Montana will use a telescope network to observe planet candidates orbiting nearby stars. The planet candidates have been identified by NASA's Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS). Planets will be confirmed, their masses and orbits will be measured. The work will help create improved theories of the formation and evolution of planets with a broad range of environments. Some of the planets confirmed will be the ones that provide the best chance of detecting life in the future. The award will fund students to participate in Harvard's Banneker Institute. This undergraduate summer program focuses on recruiting under-represented minorities for a program of research, graduate school preparation, and social justice education.

The investigation will employ two dedicated robotic arrays of four 0.7-meter telescopes (MINERVA-North and MINERVA-Australis) in both hemispheres for all sky access to confirm and characterize TESS planet candidates. The facilities will perform a large scale survey to measure the orbital obliquities of approximately 180 planets, enabling a more robust understanding of formation and migration of planets as a function of the properties of the host star and their planets. MINERVA will also measure planet masses and orbital eccentricities, and search for additional planets in each system. The confirmation and characterization of new planetary systems around the bright TESS host stars will identify the best possible targets for future detailed follow up. The planets confirmed and characterized will be the ones the next generation of space-borne exoplanet missions and ground-based extremely large telescopes will prioritize to measure the detailed atmospheric compositions and will provide the best chances of detecting biomarkers. The survey will allow a more detailed understanding of planet formation and migration as a function of stellar and planetary properties. The nature of exoplanet observations generates opportunities for projects ideal for student involvement at all levels. In addition, MINERVA's dedicated array of small telescopes provides a unique platform to develop valuable instrumentation experience. MINERVA provides a scientific backbone for undergraduate research opportunities, undergraduate theses, post-baccalaureate research experience, and graduate research experience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NASA TESS spacecraft uses photometric transit observations to identify nearby exoplanet host stars by the dimunition of the star's light while a planet traverses the face of the star along our line of sight. TESS can determine the orbital period and radius of the planet, but cannot determine the planet's mass. The combination of mass and radius provides the planet's density, and allows characterization of the composition of the planet -- is it gaseous, icy, or rocky? Determination of the mass of an exoplanet requires high-precision spectrometry from ground-based telescopes. MINERVA is an array of four 0.7-meter telescopes that combine to feed a single, high-resolution spectrometer capable of high-precision measurement of stellar radial velocity. The MINERVA array is robotic, and is operated every clear night to monitor exoplanet host stars, and is well-positioned for follow-up observations of TESS targets.

A robotic telescope needs a way to select targets. Under this proposal, our MINERVA team at the University of Montana developed and implemented target scheduling algorithms to select TESS targets for follow-up observations and schedule them automatically in real-time each observing night. Of particular interest to planet formation theorists is the star-planet system "obliquity" -- the amount of alignment between the star's rotational axis and the orbital axis of the planet. MINERVA can measure obliquity using Doppler tomography (DT) observations. DT data must be acquired during a transit event, while the planet crosses in front of the host star. Our team developed and implemented an algorithm to identify useful transit events (those which occur at night, above the horizon, on stars bright enough for our spectrometer) and pre-empted all other observations during these events.

During the 2020-21 observing season, which was limited to March-June 2021 by the global COVID pandemic, our scheduler obtained 530 spectra of 24 systems. This includes DT observations of 13 separate systems, with as many as 35 spectra during a single transit. In the 2021-22 observing season, our scheduler obtained 2,252 spectra of 39 systems, including DT observations of 8 separate systems, with as many as 30 spectra during a single transit. In the 2022-23 observing season, our scheduler obtained 1,351 spectra of 41 systems, including DT observations of 7 separate systems, with as many as 29 spectra during a single transit.

The scheduling algorithm built and maintained by the UM team with support from this grant enabled MINERVA to collect the data to characterize these TESS targets of interest, and to probe the planetary system architecture for systems well-positioned for DT observations. These scheduling programs continue to identify and prioritize TESS targets for follow-up spectrometric observations and provide new data for system characterization beyond the grant period.
